Hello Colin, 

I found that (and the animations) very helpful. Thanks for t=
he wonderful explanation!

I second Ken=E2=80=99s very interesting question=
. Do we need the equivalent of RMS-Prop for mutation rates?

Best regards,
=
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor, Computer Science
Director, Evolving Artifi=
cial Intelligence Lab <http://evolvingai.org/>
University of Wyoming
jeffcl=
une@...
jeffclune.com

> On May 7, 2015, at 2:20 PM, kstanley@...=
s.edu [neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
> 
> Colin, thanks for summarizi=
ng RMS-Prop and I'm glad to see you're still around!  Your explanation was =
very intuitive.
> 
> I'm curious, how do you think evolution with a random =
uniform mutation distribution compares to RMS-Prop or regular SGD?  Would i=
t tend to act like GD and kind of slow down on shallow gradient dimensions,=
 or would it be more even-handed like RMS-Prop, or perhaps something in the=
 middle?  
> 
> Best,
> 
> ken
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_8C00410C-1547-436D-9E59-740F8145995D
